Comment:
I liked the little nuances of the movie. !!!!!!SPOILER ALERT!!!!!!!









When Brad Pitt asks Norman if he's down some killin' and Norman replies no, Pitt tosses him the grease gun and tells Grady to teach him how to use it. Grady says something to the effect of..."You see that right there? Open it: now you killin, close it: now ya ain't."
The scene where Gordo his describing the scene a few days after Normandy. Just shows you how much war traumatizes people.
All of Bible's teary eyed scenes. Many more scenes to count.
And the fact that they didn't really shine a light on war, they certainly didn't try to make it look like such a glorious thing. Sure there were Americans in this movie and they were kickin' ass, but in the end most of them died horrible deaths. We're so used to seeing violence that we wont even bat an eye for that kind of violence. If you stop to think, there is no rhetoric for violence anywhere and especially not in war. Violence is a terrible thing for us to experience no matter what the circumstance. Fury is not a movie about characters like Saving Private Ryan was and I think it's unfair to compare the two because the theme, story and overall mood are completely different. But that's the point. The characters ARE the violence, they gave it and they took it. Personally I believe getting wrapped up in specifics bogs down a movie and ruins the experience, but I also realize not to take it personal because most of the time it has nothing to do with the movie but rather how people are.

The short all of that is: watch the movie and decide for yourself. I recommend you open yourself up to feelings rather than trying to pick it apart with your mind. Perhaps you'll have the same experience that I had; a fresh look into how violence grows and becomes apart of us and how tragic it is when that happens.

Comment:
The Tiger I in this movie is an original one. It was borrowed from the tank museum in Bovington. It's an early model that was captured in Africa which you can easily determine by the commander's cupola, the wheels and also the Feifel filters (on museum pics). Later models had so-called steel wheels and a lower cupola with periscope sights. The driver also got periscope sights. There were many additional changes and if you want to know more about all the technical aspects, I recommend the books from Walter Spielberger and Thomas Jentz about the Tiger and Panther.

There's a little anecdote in a Panther book from Ryton Publications. Ernst Barkmann, one of the "Panther aces" is asked which allied tanks were the most dangerous for the Panther and he answered that on the Eastern Front, it was the Stalin tank (IS-2) and on the Western Front it was the USAAF. ;-)

Comment: Everybody, I hate to say it but that is a Sherman tank. It is the last WW2 variant, the M4A3E8 Long-barrel. And before I get people responding to me saying, "Oh well a Sherman NEVER could beat a Tiger!" Actually, yes it could. Well this version at least. Its main gun is a 76mm Gun on it, which was previously only used on tank destroyers. This gun did in fact have the power and range to penetrate a Tiger tank's armor, IF it hit it in the right spot, (I.E. Engine Compartment, Tank Treads, Ammo Compartment, ETC). Also don't forget that the Sherman, even with the heavier 76mm gun, was faster and WAY more maneuverable then the much slower and clunky Tiger. Now, I'm not saying the Tiger is a bad tank, cus it is FAR from that, but if two or three M4A3E8's went up against one or two Tigers in a short range engagement, I would probably pick the Sherman's, purely based off of their superior speed and maneuverability. Now, at a a medium-longe range engagement, that is when I would pick the Tiger, due to its far superior armor and its deadly accurate 88mm Gun. But either ways, BOTH are respectively the best tanks each either nation could produce and put on the battlefield. Now, let the hate mail begin!

Comment:
Some notes for all the people who haven't read enough into WWII armor:
1. No, that is NOT a Firefly. The tank used for filming was an M4A2E8, never actually used by the US army (although the Russians did, and they liked them quite a bit). It's meant to substitute for an M4A3E8, which the army did field. The T23 turret should be an obvious giveaway for the more knowledgeable.
2. Yes, the Sherman would be capable of taking out a Tiger. In fact, ANY M4 would be capable of taking out a Tiger; even the short 75mm could penetrate the sides at ranges of 650 meters. The 76mm can go through the sides at distances of over 2 kilometers with standard ammunition, with the front being penetrable out to about 1 km with an unangled shot (practical penetration range was more like 400 m).
3. Yes, the E8 could survive a frontal shot from a Tiger at close range, particularly at that angle. The lower glacis is thicker than the Tiger I's and well sloped to boot.
